captions.text:
What up homies? Welcome back to
Thug Notes. This week we stickin it to the
man with 1984 by George Orwell.

1984 focuses on Winston Smith,
a mid-level member of a totalitarian regime

known as The Party. Now the leader of this
gang goes by the name of Big Brotha and represents
the po-po keepin tabs on all yo shi*t.

One day my boy Winston gets fed up
wit the system and starts spittin fire up

in his journal. But dat fool gotta watch his
self cuz talkin smack about Big Bro is enough
to get a brotha thrown in the slammer.

Later, some fly hunny named Julia
straight up booty calls Winston by passing

him a note that says “I Love You.” Haell
yeah. And after a while, Winston be thinkin
he got mad love for this fox.

One day at work, Winston peeps some
cat by the name of O’Brien who seems like

he wanna stick it to Big Brother too. So Winston
brings his boo Julia to Obrien’s crib where

O’Brien say that he part of a rebel group
called “The Brotherhood.” Winston be like
“sign me up, blood.”

One night, Winston be readin some
book that O’brien gave him when BAM, the

5-O come bustin through his door and bag him
and homegirl.

Turns out, dat fool Obrien was secretly part
of Big Brother’s
Thought Police crew.

And let me tell you somethin, home
boy. These fools AIN’T PLAYIN.

In order to realign Winston with the party’s
mentality, Obrien be torturing Winston until

he admit to crimes he ain’t even done. Then
Obrien be all like “Yo. We ain’t done

up in here until everything be dead inside
you. Then after you empty, we gonna fill yo

ass up with Big Brotha-ly love.” Ain’t
that some sh*t? But Winston say “Naw shorty,
I keeps it real.”

This be one of them instances where
keepin it real goes wrong cuz dat boy Obrien

slings Winston’s ass in the wackest torture
chamber yo bitch ass ever heard of- Room 101.
So O'Brien puts a cage full of rats all up in Winston’s grill until he gives in and starts screamin
"Do it to Julia! Not me!”

In the end, The Man takes all the
‘soul’straight outta Winston.
He only love Big Brother. Damn.

Aight son, you don’t know nuthin
about Big Brotha unless you schooled on their

wackest method of control- Doublethink. Let
me break it down. It’s called doublethink
cuz yo ass be thinkin in two ways at once.

The first is you making the
conscious decision to believe something that

be obvious bullshit. The second is when you
also deny that it’s even a lie in the first

place. So in the end, youse a fool who be
believin nonsense with all the conviction

of it actually bein true. Like Obrien’s
book say, doublethink goes on forever, with

“the lie always one step ahead of the truth.”
That shit is ridiculous.

When most ballas think about Big Brotha, they
usually think about

the po-po peepin yo shit with informants and
telescreens. But what’s just as legit is
the way The Party twists reality.

See, if you wanna roll like a G-ed
up totalitarian dictator, you can’t just

tear down the truth like Hitler, whose dumbass
actually burned books that weren’t feeling

his flow. Naw, you gotta build that shit back
up like Stalin, who actually rewrote those

muthafuckas to be in line with his flava.
Orwell’s Oceania be givin nods to Stalin,

who was sho as hell better at controllin his
peeps than Hitler.

Yo, you know what else is whack? As
the party recreates reality, eventually all

yo individual qualities get kicked straight
to the curb.
How’s a brotha gonna know he exist

if all he be is what the government tells
him he be?

But let me be clear son. If you
think this book just be a critique of Stalinism,

you best check yo self blood. Cuz on the real,
this book here is a warning for ALL mankind.

Orwell sayin “Yo. unless we change shit
up in here,

we gonna become soulless robots
and not even know it!”
Hey, thank you for checking out Thug Notes

Don't be a playa hater man, hit subscribe
and see you next week.

title: 1984 (Nineteen Eighty-Four) - Thug Notes Summary and Analysis

comments.text:
+Kilyle  Lots of great stuff to discuss in that post. Let's start with 
number one: something from nothing.

From my knowledge of modern physics (which is admittedly amateur), reality 
is not said to have sprung from nothing. As you said, that would break 
causality. Rather, reality has always existed (though not our particular 
universe). And the big bang is part of some cyclical mechanism from which 
our universe emerges.

But that's theory and unknowable (currently, anyway). It also doesn't 
matter since there is a better argument.

If it's required for *the universe* to have a cause, it follows that a 
*creator* must also have a cause. If you hold that causality is axiomatic, 
then it must hold true universally. If reality had to be created then a 
creator must also require a creator and so forth.
comments.author: slicedtoad

comments.text:
+slicedtoad I have a lot more sympathy for people leaving cults after I 
spent about six months weighing what I'd have to believe if the world were 
not the way I'd been raised to think it was. Holding two conflicting 
viewpoints at the same time when you're not sure which is correct is a kind 
of mental anguish that I had never before experienced, and it went on 
without letup unless I tried very hard not to think about it, and I hope to 
never experience it again.

Eventually I figured out this much, from which I was able to build most of 
the rest of what I believe now (less certain than I was growing up, but on 
a more solid foundation, I think):

In order for this reality to exist without any intelligent force behind its 
creation, there would have to be:

1. *Something* that came from *nothing*.
2. *Energy* that came from *nonenergy*.
3. *Matter* that came from *nonmatter*.
4. *Order* that came from *chaos*.
5. *Information* that came from *noninformation*.
6. *Life* that came from *nonlife* (several factors, including eating and 
excreting, growing, reproducing).
7. *Sexual reproduction* that came from *asexual reproduction* (and note 
that this has to happen to two separate entities at the same time).
8. *Memory* that came from *nonmemory*.
9. *Sentience* that came from *nonsentience*.
10. *Creativity* that came from *noncreativity*.
11. *Morality* that came from *amorality* (because torturing an infant for 
your own amusement is wrong for any being at any time in any culture in all 
realities, and if this fact is not true then everything else, *everything* 
else breaks into shards and nothing matters).

...pretty sure I had more than that but it's late and I can't remember them.

Anyway, the first one breaks the idea of causality, the second breaks the 
idea of thermodynamics, the fourth breaks the idea of entropy, and the list 
in general makes a sense of probability meaningless. Without *compelling* 
evidence that these things all happened, I can't bring myself to believe 
them because they are patently ridiculous. It's like trying to believe in a 
library without any authors or, perhaps more accurately, a Steam library 
without any programmers.

That plus the variety of symbiotic lifeforms got me from nothing to the 
idea of some form of powerful, super-intelligent designer. And I don't know 
any way to conceive that other than theism. So I started investigating 
theism variants to see which one made the most sense.

Regardless, I'll never be able to believe my way back down that list again. 
So that's a kind of solid ground for me, at least.

P.S. If you see two identical beings who seem to be Johnny Depp, and find 
that it is impossible to tell which one is the real Johnny Depp and which 
one is actually a robot duplicate, because the robot duplicate is just that 
good at duplicating Johnny Depp (up to and including organic processes such 
as eating food), does it make any sense at all to ask who designed a robot 
that well but *not* ask a similar question about the designer of Johnny 
Depp himself?
comments.author: Kilyle

comments.author: spartenkiller897

comments.text:
+evie bklyn So, props on breaking with the cult worship and all.
But, given that you're human, there are some tendencies you might want to 
be aware of.

The people you grow up with have a significant impact on you. In fact, many 
sociologists argue that your early-life environment entirely determines how 
you think (so basically "who you are").

Of course, the obvious counter is "but I left that" (rebelled, shed, 
distanced, rejected, etc). The somewhat depressing reality is that almost 
everyone just manages to flip to the other side of the coin.

Moving to the opposite of something does not free you from it's influence. 
Your actions are still "slave" to it, just inverted. Your mind still 
processes things in the same irrational way. This is almost never 
recognized by the individual, but quite agreed upon by sociologists.

Let's look at Atheists. Notice I'm using a capitol 'A'. I'm not discussing 
the scientific perspective on deities. *That* perspective has been quite 
good at moving progress forward.

But for the group that does not practice anything related to science and 
yet *defines (labels) themselves by their non-belief in a deity*... They 
are just as trapped in dogma as their religious counterparts.

The theist judges values based on *ethos* (authority). An argument 
supported by an appeal to authority is not *always* wrong, of course. If a 
biologist says something about biology, it makes sense to weigh his 
argument higher than someone else's.

But to make all you life decisions based on the say-so of a church leader 
is insane. *Likewise to make ethical, social or political judgement based 
on the authority of a physicist.*

So, unless you are exceptional (literally), to actually escape the 
religious "chains", you need to become very introspective. Question 
everything about yourself. Critique every thought, especially those related 
to ethics and identity. Go back over your values and try to find their 
source.

Find the areas of your mind that are painful. The parts you shy away from. 
That's where your dogma is.

Look at the values that you despise. Why do you despise them? Is it in 
reaction to your upbringing? That's bias. Kill it with fire (or 
realistically, by chipping away at it).

Or don't. Just be part of the post-christian Atheist crowd, rebelling but 
not actually changing except in name. Eventually, I imagine the dogma will 
fade and is hopefully replaced by something healthier. But it'd be nice if 
it would happen sooner rather than a century from now.

comments.text:
George Orwell was strongly marxist. Animal Farm is a critique of the sort 
of fascism that went on under the disguise of "communism" in the USSR. 
Orwell realizes that totalitarianism and socialism are opposites, not 
synonyms. He even wrote Homage to Catalonia, where he tells his story of 
fighting on the socialist side in the spanish revolution. He also stated 
that everything he ever wrote was "against totalitarianism and for 
democratic socialism": Peace comrade.
comments.author: Johan Mendes

comments.text:
+Death the _id
Right from the jump you began your reply concerning yourself with what 
others have by bringing up what others inherit.  That right there is my 
problem with the "good people" on the left. That is simply energy wasted on 
your part, concern yourself with what you want out of life, form your plan, 
and get to it. Do not waste your time worrying what others have or what 
they inherit.(By the way, you will likely inherit more than I will)

When you say I would have been a progressive in the past... I have been a 
progressive in the past.  When I speak with local progressives at my door 
when they want me to recall the Republican Gov Walker, they even tell me I 
should be one of them, as I am more progressive than them in many ways(avid 
organic gardener, drive a ultra low emmision Honda), but I do not vote 
left, and I do not covet what others have, I do not support "man made 
climate change" that is intended it pass carbon taxes and credits, and I 
strongly support the 2nd amendment after being pistol whipped during an 
armed robbery in 2004.

Health and safety are my two greatest interests in life, and I feel 
carrying a concealed firearm is the safest thing a person can do.  Months 
after I was pistol whipped, Wisconsin passed a concealed carry bill, only 
to have Dem Gov Jim Doyle veto the bill.  His mansion was less than one 
mile from the business I was working at when pistol-whipped, and he had 
armed guards on the States dime at said mansion... Fucking hypocrite.
 
It took Republican Gov Scott Walker to get Wisconsin's concealed carry bill 
passed, and thankfully I am now and licensed to carry, and I carry each and 
every day.  The Leftists said the sky would fall...

I could go into the health aspects, but I'm just going to end this here, 
but I did want to reply to your comment about how "There still should be a 
regulation on how much fish a single person gets"  There is(1 per day), and 
no muskie fisherman Ever keeps or intentionally kills a single fish.  We 
take quick photos, and we quickly release them... Most have spent hundreds 
in safe release equipment(I sold my Beckman release net for $100 used!) and 
a proper hook cutter(Knipex) is $50 alone.  Any muskie fisherman that 
accidently kills a muskie takes a ton of shit from every other fisherman 
for doing so.  When water temps reach 80Fdegrees, 99% quit fishing because 
it is too hard on the fish.

We fish for photos alone, and if guys catch one stupid huge(well over 50") 
they may spend $500+ on a fiberglass replica.... Would you still like to 
place a limit on how many fish a single person can catch?

PS. Back to a Hendrix quote I made in an earlier post "When the power of 
love overcomes the lover of power, the World will know peace"  As long as 
we keep putting those in power that desire power, we have the wrong people 
running the show. The community organizers that are always speaking about 
what others have, are doing so to manipulate you for your vote so they can 
achieve power.  Just like Animal Farm.

 Look into Dr Ben Carson the brain surgeon.  The man did not want to run 
for President, but after years of folks begging him to run he is 
considering it.  He is a brilliant Black brain surgeon that came from the 
bottom, and worked his way to the top... And most leftists hate him.  I do 
not yet know enough about him to say I would vote for him, but he sure 
would make for an interesting candidate coming form outside politics. He is 
soft spoken, but the man has a pair, and has no fear of speaking truth.
comments.author: WisconsinEric

comments.text:
+WisconsinEric The problem with your fishing analogy is that, A.No one can 
inherit their fathers muskies, they *HAVE* to work for them. and B.There 
still should be regulations on how much fish a single person gets, because 
of environmental reasons. But anyway being progressive doesn't mean that 
you want to bring others down, it's wanting to allow others a chance to get 
up. For example, you could say pre 1960's that a black person, if they 
worked hard enough, had a chance of succeeding, but if you were 
Asian(usually) or white, then you wouldn't have to work nearly half as 
hard. Shouldn't there be a change made? If you agree, then you would have 
been a progressive at the time. (I would also argue that Marxism isn't as 
bad as you think, but that's neither here nor there)
comments.author: Death the _id

comments.text:
+Death the _id
I will start off saying I was born, raised, and public schooled in the most 
progressive city in the Nation, Madison Wi.  If memory serves me correct, 
the progressive party may have began in Wisconsin.

Lets talk about the "evil 1%" or whatever the rhetoric is these days coming 
from the hardcore leftists, progressives, demon crats whatever you call 
them.

I will begin with a personal example that opened my eyes a bit, because I 
used to a progressive, and I used to whine about those "evil 1%" making all 
the money...

 Years ago I used to be a hardcore muskie fisherman, muskies being the most 
difficult freshwater fish to catch...  Now good fisherman/women have a 
saying that is based in truth, and it translates to All aspects of life...

Good fishermen/women know that on any given day, the best 10% or less of 
the fishermen/women catch more than 90% of all fish caught...  Now if your 
not one of those less than 10% that is being successful, you have two 
options, you can whine about fishing inequality, or you can set a goal, and 
form a plan how to achieve said goal, and then put your work in.  Heck, you 
can even speak politely to those successful top less than 10% and they may 
throw you some pointers, but they are not going to do the work for you.

Or you can go the other route and whine about fishing inequality, but that 
will accomplish nothing more than earning you points with other losers.  
But then if you make a great organizer, you could figure out a way to 
organize enough losers to put some sort of limit on the success of those 
less than 10% that catch more than 90% of the fish...

Now when you read this you likely think I must be a well off elitist, but I 
will inform you that I currently live below the poverty line, but I do not 
waste my time worrying about what rich folks have. Instead I set a goal 
years ago, and that goal was to get my health back after it was taken from 
me in a car crash when an elderly woman fell asleep behind the wheel of her 
Buick and rear ended me. 

Over and over I have accomplished goals that others(including Doctors) said 
I could not accomplish, and I did not accomplish them by whining about what 
others have.  I set goals, and I form long term plans on how to achieve 
said goals.  Then I put my work in.

I may still be a loser by many peoples measure, but I don't waste my 
limited time and strength worrying what others think or have.

When you write that I am "Clearly not open minded" you have me flat out 
wrong, I am greener than the greenies(but not a greenie), more of a hippie 
than the hippies(but not a hippie), and I love all people(except the commie 
progressive demon crats that always want to take from those more successful 
than themselves)   Sad times, as the Marxist rhetoric is everywhere these 
days.

I hope you have a good healthy day.
comments.author: WisconsinEric

comments.text:
I'm unclear how being progressive is bad. Wanting people to not be treated

comments.author: Death the _id

comments.text:
+DonutUnderpants
My original comment 5 months ago stated I last read the book 20yrs ago... 
back when I 14-15yrs old.... Where were you 20yrs ago?

I get that Animal Farm was written in code, and it was meant to show that 
those in power, AND those seeking power are all corrupt.

In that post I made 5 months ago I stated that  what is most relevant today 
is the language being used about the "evil elitist 1%" by those seeking 
power today. Stupid people will always vote for free lunch(Healthcare for 
all!) But soon they find there is no free lunch.

In my opinion worrying about what others have is a waste of time. Instead 
think about what you want from life, and form a plan on how to achieve it 
without stepping on toes(taking from others)

One of my favorite quotes... "When the power of love overcomes the love of 
power, the World will know peace". Jimi Hendrix

And for the record, I am very much against Marxism, Socialism, and 
Communism. Sure things are fucked up in the US at the moment, but the 
pendulum is about to swing...
comments.author: WisconsinEric

comments.text:
+WisconsinEric LOL. You didn't understand Animal Farm, apparently. That 
book was just as much a critique of Western governments as it was a 
critique of Marxism.

comments.author: Ajay Adrie

comments.text:
+117MCT In my English Literature class, we were forced to read this book. 
It's a shame, because I almost certainly would have read it on my own at 
some point. Instead, we had to read it painstakingly slowly, with essays 
and tests practically once a week. It turned a great book into a hellish 
experience.

What's sad and pathetic is that there exist required classes that tell us 
to read something, and then promptly disregard our own interpretations in 
favor of simply making us use their own. What's sad and pathetic is that 
any dissent is punished by lower grades and referrals to the principal's 
office. What's sad and pathetic is that classes that are supposed to be 
teaching this book are, instead, becoming analogous to this book.


English Literature class is the place where there is "someone giving you 
all the answers". Of course, they're not the correct answers, because the 
answers are typically subjective. But they're still the answers we have to 
use, or else.


Maybe if we were allowed to just read the damn books on our own as opposed 
to being forced through them by stupid, useless classes, maybe then reading 
would be something that people enjoyed, rather than something they dread 
and hate.
comments.author: Helpful Hazz

comments.text:
